skills.name: Enlarge a shape, with a centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1, where the centre of enlargement lies on the edge or outside of the object
Enlarge a shape, with a centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1, where the centre of enlargement lies within the object
Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1

explanations.A: You've worked out the scale factor if shape B is enlarged to get shape A. We want the scale factor when shape A is enlarged to get shape B.
explanations.B: The height of shape A is 1 and the height of shape B is 3 so we can see that shape B is three times as big as shape A, so the scale factor is 3.
explanations.C: Think about the length of the sides on shape A. What have they been multiplied by to get the lengths of the sides on Shape B?
explanations.D: I think you might be thinking about the area here. Instead, think about what we need to multiply a side length on shape A by to get the matching side length on shape B.

explanations.A: Think about the length of the sides on shape A. What have they been multiplied by to get the lengths of the sides on Shape B?
explanations.B: I think you might be thinking about the area here. Instead, think about what we need to multiply a side length on shape A by to get the matching side length on shape B.
explanations.C: The width of shape A is 1 and the width of shape B is 2 so we can see that shape B is twice as big as shape A, so the scale factor is 2.
explanations.D: You've worked out the scale factor if shape B is enlarged to get shape A. We want the scale factor when shape A is enlarged to get shape B.

explanations.A: I think you've counted 3 along the x axis from the origin (0,0). Remember the red vertex should be 3 times further away from the centre of enlargement at (0,0) than it was to begin with.
explanations.B: Point B is twice as far from the centre of enlargement at the origin (0,0) as the red vertex. But remember the scale factor is 3 so how many times further away do we need the point to be?
explanations.C: The scale factor is 3 so we need a point that is three times as far from the centre of enlargement at the origin (0,0) as the original point (2,1). To get from (0,0) to (2,1), we move 2 across and 1 up. To get from (0,0) to the new point on the enlarged shape, we need to move 3 x 2 = 6 across and 3 x 1 = 3 up. So the red vertex is enlarged to (6,3), point C.
explanations.D: I think you counted squares across and up from the red vertex. Remember to always start counting from centre of enlargement, in this case the origin (0,0).

explanations.A: I think you may have counted the squares in the wrong directions. To get from the centre of enlargement at the origin (0,0) to the red vertex, we go 4 squares across and 2 squares up. We need to make sure we do the same again to double the distance from the centre of enlargement.
explanations.B: I think you counted squares across and up from the red vertex. Remember to always start counting from centre of enlargement, in this case the origin (0,0).
explanations.C: The scale factor is 2 so we need a point that is twice as far from the centre of enlargement at the origin (0,0) as the original point (4,2). To get from (0,0) to (4,2), we move 4 across and 2 up. To get from (0,0) to the new point on the enlarged shape, we need to move 2 x 4 = 8 across and 2 x 2 = 4 up. So the red vertex is enlarged to (8,4), point C.
explanations.D: Be careful, you've used a scale factor of Â½ here. We need a scale factor of 2.

explanations.A: I think you've counted 1.5 squares in each direction (x and y) from the origin (0,0). Remember the green vertex needs to be 1.5 times further away from the centre of enlargement (0,0) than it was to begin with.
explanations.B: The green vertex is 2 squares right and 2 squares up from the centre of enlargement (0,0). When multiplied by 1.5, this point will be 1.5 x 2 = 3 squares right and 1.5 x 2 = 3 squares up from (0,0) at (3,3), which is point B.
explanations.C: I think you counted 3 squares up and across from the green vertex. Remember to always start counting from centre of enlargement, in this case the origin.
explanations.D: It looks like you may have tried to enlarge the base. Remember that all the vertices on the enlarged shape will be 1.5 times further away from the centre of enlargement at (0,0) than before. It might help to enlarge the whole shape first and then identify the position of the green vertex.

explanations.A: The green vertex is 2 squares right and 2 squares up from the centre of enlargement (0,0). When multiplied by 1.5, this point will be 1.5 x 2 = 3 squares right and 1.5 x 2 = 3 squares up from (0,0) at (3,3), which is point A.
explanations.B: It looks like you may have enlarged the wrong vertex. We are interested in the green vertex at the bottom right of the shape.
explanations.C: I think you counted 3 squares up and across from the green vertex. Remember to always start counting from centre of enlargement, in this case the origin (0,0).
explanations.D: I think you've counted 1.5 squares in each direction (x and y) from the origin (0,0). Remember the green vertex needs to be 1.5 times further away from the centre of enlargement (0,0) than it was to begin with.

explanations.A: I think you may have miscounted the number of squares. Remember the scale factor is 2 and we need to measure from the point marked X.
explanations.B: Point B is three times as far from the centre of enlargement X as the vertex at (3,4). But remember the scale factor is 2 so how far away from X do we need the point to be?
explanations.C: The vertex at (3,4) is 2 squares down from the centre of enlargement X. When multiplied by a scale factor of 2, this point will be 2 x 2 = 4 squares down from X at (3,2), which is point C.
explanations.D: The scale factor is positive so the new point should be on the same side of the centre of enlargement X as the vertex at (3,4).

explanations.A: I think you've enlarged the wrong vertex. (5,4) is at the top right of the triangle.
explanations.B: The vertex at (5,4) is 2 squares right and 1 square down from the centre of enlargement X. When multiplied by a scale factor of 2, the new vertex will be 2 x 2 = 4 squares right and 2 x 1 = 2 squares down from X at (7,3), which is point B.
explanations.C: Point C is three times as far from the centre of enlargement X as the vertex at (5,4). But remember the scale factor is 2 so how far away from X do we need the point to be?
explanations.D: The scale factor is positive so the new point should be on the same side of the centre of enlargement X as the vertex at (5,4).

explanations.A: Point A is twice as far (2 squares up) from the centre of enlargement as the vertex at (4,5) so it would be a correct vertex of the enlarged shape. Remember we are trying to find a point which would NOT be a vertex of the enlarged shape.
explanations.B: Point B is twice as far (4 squares right) from the centre of enlargement as the vertex at (6,4) so it would be a correct vertex of the enlarged shape. Remember we are trying to find a point which would NOT be a vertex of the enlarged shape.
explanations.C: Point C is twice as far (2 squares right and 2 squares down) from the centre of enlargement as the vertex at (5,3) so it would be a correct vertex of the enlarged shape. Remember we are trying to find a point which would NOT be a vertex of the enlarged shape.
explanations.D: The vertex at (2, 4) is 2 squares to the left of the centre of enlargement. The scale factor is 2 so the enlarged vertex should be 2 x 2 squares = 4 squares to the left of the centre of enlargement but Point D is actually 5 squares to the left. So point D would not be a vertex in the enlarged image.
